147281818.review:
I've always been searching for that perfect tycoon game and this hits the sweet spot. It's got all the fun of setting up and operating successful businesses while using the drug theme as a way to keep it different and interesting. If you are looking for a business management/tycoon game that's not too overly complex, but still has a lot of depth to fine tune things, this is the game for you!

Been playing this game since the day it released into early access and I have loved every minute of it. There is just something super satisfying about setting up the factory and businesses and watching it all come together in harmony. It's also incredibly satisfying to start off with just a basic set up and watch it grow into a empire with multiple drug types and tiers.

I also personally enjoy the art style of the game. It gives a somewhat simple feel to the game while still including enough details to really see whats happening in the world.

To sum it all up, DNFC is an amazing business management game themed around drug trade. It's incredibly satisfying to play, visually pleasing to look at, and has a banger soundtrack to boot.

I seriously cannot recommend this game enough.

145563792.review:
This game is definitely a good start to a tycoon game. Knowing that it's in early access, I am looking forward to more expansion on narcotics trade as a whole. There are so many challenges that could be added in, from DEA raids, selling to cops and being punished, dealing with customers who are active in addiction then go to rehab so you lose sales, and investigations from the government. 

As it stands, [i]Definitely Not Fried Chicken[/i] trends in a way that seems to glamorize the cartel lifestyle, without showing the really heinous parts of drug manufacturing and use. I am not displeased with the weed part of the game, its fun for the most part. Making edibles and prerolls would be a cool addition, as well as a campaign to legalize so you can have a legit store like we do in the better parts of the U.S. 

With the meth update, that's where my liking of this game went south. Knowing someone who has recovered from meth abuse, this is [i]insultingly[/i] simplified. Meth is a serious drug that ruins lives and families, its not so easy that people can just buy it once and wait. They should be pounding on the door for it. There should be tweakers busting into cars and robbing stores, I want to see the *real* things that go down with the drug industry, as it stands now, there just isn't enough depth.

I hope the devs can learn from people who are either in active addiction or have become sober. There is so much more to this lifestyle that is completely omitted. It seems like a game made by a fan of Breaking Bad, not someone who has [i]any[/i] knowledge of how the illicit drug world works whatsoever.

143778424.review:
[b]Definitely Not Fried Chicken  was featured on my YouTube channel[/b]


https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3017965615


and now onto the short review

[h1]TL;DR Review[/h1]




//intro//

Welcome back comrades, this is MF Kraven & you are watching less than 10 mins reviews. The Youtube series where I take a look at games i think seem cool & give my thoughts on them in less than 10 mins. I review games in the following format, Buy it Now! Wait for Sale & Do Not Buy!

Today I'm gonna be taking a look at an EARLY ACCESS version Definitely Not Fried Chicken, a business management sim with a Break Bad twist. Start off as a humble entrepreneur hiring local inner-city farmers & chemists then buy out lots to launder I mean invest in Laundromats, Donut Shops, Fried Chicken & Seafood restaurants. (Night Clubs & Casinos coming at a later date). Have your base of operations distribute your narcotics throughout the city while in competition with a chicken icon in The Major. Could you be this quaint town's new kingpin? Or is DNFC Definitely Not a Good time? Lets find out.



//Graphics, Sound & Artstyle//

There's a grimy box pixel art type of aesthetic that perfectly suits this game, the sfx are phenomenal- while a bit repetitive at times, I can clearly hear when my workers are being productive with as much going on. Its welcoming to be able to make it out. The music, just doesn't resonate with me.


//Gameplay//

If you like a meticulous micromanagement business sim, this is the one for you. Hire workers for your growhouse from Peons, Engineers, Cleaners and even security. Set their schedules so they dont burn out but also enough to produce product to move. Get a few garages to send your product on mopeds, have them go to specific customers in a map & route them out. Don't like only sending one pound of product? Send some over to the junkyard to unlock cars & trucks to move even more product. Want to grow different strains or even get in the more lucrative field of narcotics? Send some over to the university & they'll start selling you their stuff. But surely with as much money as you will be making, people will notice right? Buy out lots & build business to keep the fuzz off your back- or also distribute directly to customers from your business. Set schedules for your business and make passive income the.. legal way. 




//Price//

24.99 USD


//How many hours estimated//

I'm only about 6.5 hours in, and ive only touched the surface I believe. Its a slow grind but very much one of those, let me just get 15 more mins in type of games.


//Is it Playable on Steamdeck?//

While it is playable, I wouldn't recommend it for SteamDeck. You have to be meticulous about your scheduling and going back & forth between lots until you have that perfect schedule set that allows you to bring enough income in to warrant leaving it alone. 


//Wishlist//

*Ability to move rooms, as of now you have to kind of completely renovate everything
*Promotions- giving the ability for workers to make other workers take a break or open businesses without you.
*More vehicles for transporting product, 2 & 3 package vehicles like smaller car or a bigger moped that can load 2
*Options to start selling higher quality narcotics at start, I couldn't open a restaurant because I hadn't unlocked the equipment to make the harder stuff.
*the ability to rename workers, & shops
*you setting the hours for your businesses, I mean I grew up around shady 24 hr Laundromats & Donut Shops.
*setting prices. for the product, for the washing machines, dryers, gumball machines, detergent. setting the prices a bit higher would be nice.
*multiple businesses on a single lot. lets say like a strip mall where you can take your dry cleaning to, can grab a donut & maybe even an arcade 
*more business types! like i mentioned, dry cleaning, arcade, skating rink, mattress stores, just a bunch of business types that everyone questions how they're in business despite never seeing anyone in there.
*better UI
*finally, more drug types. 



//Final Thoughts//

I absolutely love Definitely Not Fried Chicken. The silly animations, the in depth mechanics, I spent a hell of a lot longer making my laundromat the way I wanted it though, while I allowed the factory or grow-house to just do whatever they wanted (i did have to hire a few workers when I did check back at the grow-house because id work em to death). I'm about 7 hours in and I still haven't even made my donut, chicken or seafood restaurant, I love the hard grind but therein lies some problems.

With workers, their needs are always deteriorating. But if you don't have em on a scheduled break they just wont do anything. I've set a system for my business with Schedule 0,1,2. On 0 they work from 0600 to 1900 but if i see they're unhappy i will switch em over to 1, with is basically break time all day except for 2000 to 23000 when it's time to receive a package from my growhouse, 2 is to send em home. I'm still tinkering with scheduling but that seems to be the best for me yet sometimes it's a bit overwhelming. If I go over to improve the growhouse and forget to open the Laundromat then i miss on having passive income that has certainly helped me. Why not leave it open then you ask? Because my machines need maintenance every single day, so I hire an engineer to come and fix em. Cant exactly bring him over when I forget to switch him over to schedule 0. I'd love little reminders or even a "phone call or text" from my workers to say "hey boss are we open today or nah". Any prompt really. I'd also love to have a ranking system for workers. Like they can level up and be supervisor, manager etc to give them a bit more responsibility & help your crew in need. Why cant the cleaner who just stands around when she's done also accept product? It's not like they dont clean the warehouse where we keep narcotics?

Also while I'm enjoying the long grind, it seems pretty daunting to unlock everything you need to make more money. 90 pts or 45 packages of good weed or 90 packages of bad weed to unlock a car! Now that I've replaced my mopeds with cars, I don't always have enough product to move. The dispatch system also seems kinda broken. If we get so much hands on work, why not allow our dispatchers to deliver certain kind of product to one customer and while having another one highlighted deliver the rest to that one? Once you get a hotline, customers will light it up to get you to deliver to them, its only until recently however that i realized i could charge more for a promise of better quality product. 

And if I'm being completely honest, ive been having a HELL of a good time just running my little laundromat. Getting all the permits to get the absolute best equipment, maximizing my passive income, while also managing the workers there. I almost forget, oh yeah we're running a drug line here 


As a shell, this game has the potential to be one of the greatest of all time. So good on the devs for releasing this in EA. While it is almost finished besides adding (ocaine, nightclubs & casinos) the game would be a LOT better with some tweaks (no pun intended) here and there. I have a wishlist since Jan, so for me this is def worth a buy However buyer be warned that this is an extremely niche title.






I guess it's a tricky one but if you were on the fence about getting it, BUY IT NOW! & if you're just shopping around, WAIT FOR SALE! 





[h1]Buy it Now![/h1]

142437965.review:
Great game. At its core, it's a resource management and supply lines game. 

At this point in development, it is very reminiscent of someone's free-to-play flash-game passion-project. There's a lot there, it's fun, it's creative, but it's jank and very little QOL implemented. But there's a lot of potential, and the devs are active in development. 

Speaking to the inevitable early-access jank:
After running for 2 or 3 hours it gets glitchy and the AI bugs-out and build-mode gets funky. Everything breaks down, but it is still technically playable, just the AI might keep going around in circles or walk around the entire property to use the rear door rather than walk out back. If you enter build-mode and place some rooms, the price will stick on your mouse through gameplay until you go back into build-mode and select then de-select remove room tool. At least, that's the fastest way I've found to fix that. Also, when placing room tiles, the flooring textures won't change. You'll have a dirty, earthen floor until you restart the game. Then everything fixes itself and the floors appear properly and the AI behaves normally. 
If any of these things happen, it's definitely worth a restart as the others are not far behind.

The QOL mechanics are bare-bones. So much is missing from it, as other reviews have pointed-out. Transporting your goods via vehicles seems like an okay system at first, but there is very little customization to it, no custom labeling to easily tell one from another, no customizing their loads numerically (you can flag it open to multiple drugs, but how much is added of each is random and up to the AI, which is also randomly performing whatever tasks you've flagged for them), etc. They will depart from your "factory" only when full, and will attempt to stop at the chosen destination. If it can't, it'll keep circling the block until there's space. Once it reaches its destination it will sit there until others unload it. If you are trying to ship resources to one of your businesses, and the shelf storage for a particular drug is full, the vehicle will sit there indefinitely until space is freed and the last drug is unloaded from the vehicle, or if you manually tell it to return to the factory. That can REALLY fuck with your supply-chain. Also, since flagging a vehicle to multiple drugs just lets the AI randomly load things into it (no numerically customization), it's DEFINITELY worth buying a separate vehicle and using only a single drugs per vehicle. That gets to be an expensive upkeep, but that's the best system I've found. Also, once you have enough drugs to make that especially expensive, you've probably making a whole lot of money, anyway. Businesses make a good profit, even without your drugs. The Laundromat, not-so-much (it's a laundromat. No expensive dry-cleaning, just the cheap washers and dryers, and the businesses all have a maximum capacity determined by the star-rating. That is another complain of mine. Bustling businesses are a myth because of this maximum capacity that is enforced, regardless of accomodations).
I'd LOVE to see a blue-print system implemented into the game. Construction can get tedious, and I find myself constantly looking back to my older businesses to look at the design I thought worked well so I can copy that over to the new business. Cut/copy/paste would also be great. Moving a room as a whole, extending a wall, etc. What they got works, but it's missing some QOL improvements. Looking at this, I've really taken The Sims building mode for granted.

It's still early-access, and the developers are active. That's promising. This game has a lot of potential, and I'd hate to see it abandoned any time soon.

141973693.review:
[h1]80's Business Chic Meets Shadowy Thrills: Welcome to Definitely Not Fried Chicken![/h1]

Take a step into the vibrant, sunlit world of Definitely Not Fried Chicken (DNFC) - a business management sim that beautifully intertwines the allure of the 80s with the thrill of covert operations. As the saying goes, all that glitters isn't gold; and in DNFC, all that fries certainly isn't chicken.

In DNFC, you're no mere observer. Instead, you're an active participant in the bustling cityscape, donning the dual hat of a respected entrepreneur and a secretive narcotics mogul. DNFC's tutorial offers you a compass to navigate this complex labyrinth. However, like a master painter with a canvas, it provides you the tools but leaves the masterpiece creation to you.

The game's charm is skillfully baked into its attention to detail. Each decision, from buying plots for your drug compound, mapping production lines, to orchestrating distribution routes, impacts your empire. Couple this with the task of safeguarding your operations from prying eyes, and you have an intricate, immersive world that rewards both strategy and creativity.

Yet, the game’s essence doesn't lie solely in the clandestine operations. The vibrant townsfolk, with their outrageous demands, add a splash of color to your journey. Fulfilling their eccentric requests not only unlocks secret costumes but also provides an enjoyable respite from your core operations, amplifying DNFC’s appeal.

Maintaining your cover through proper management of your 'legal' businesses is just as crucial. Whether it's streamlining your kitchen staff's efficiency, scheduling the unloading of trucks, or ensuring customer satisfaction, every detail pulls you deeper into DNFC's meticulously crafted narrative.

Granted, DNFC is in early access, and there are still pieces of this intriguing puzzle to be unveiled. However, this doesn't detract from the game's current allure. Instead, it whets your appetite for what's yet to come.

Having clocked a whopping 56.9 hours, it's clear that DNFC is more than a mere tycoon/management sim. It's a game that stirs your entrepreneurial instincts, challenges your strategic skills, and rewards you with a rich, immersive experience that is equal parts exciting and rewarding.

In conclusion, if you're hunting for a management sim that offers an audacious twist on the genre, Definitely Not Fried Chicken is your answer. With its rich narrative, engaging gameplay, and beautifully crafted world, it's a digital playground you won't want to leave!

Score: 9.5/10 - [i]"A sublime journey into the glitz and glamour of the 80s, where running a business is as thrilling as it is rewarding. Don't miss out on this rollercoaster of a game!"[/i]

-Selling product through phone orders compared to in store doesn't make sense; especially timed orders. 
Example 1---3 star amazonian in store is sold for $495 per box but $1584 for 8 boxes through phone order.
Example 2---3 star clear in store is sold for $1000 per box but $3600 for 8 boxes through phone order.
The math aint mathin on these sales. I know you get a little bit more for timed orders(which should be double or triple since its such a short amount of time) but this needs to change.

I picked up this game last week and have been really enjoying it! 

It's still in early access but there is a lot that you can do to have fun in the game. I strongly enjoy this game but do have some ideas for the developers after playing for a bit.

Re-playability: I would really really really enjoy seeing this concept fleshed out a bit more in depth. I feel like the game progression in your vision is to Grow Weed -> Cook Meth -> Produce Coke. I propose a concept of choose your end-game where you can flesh out each drug empire as their own path. IF a player wishes, they can dabble in multiple drug trades. However I would find it very interesting if you could get to End-Game while fine-tuning one of the drug trades. 

Example: The Cannabis production -  Stretch it out 

The player is able to go from Cannabis to Toasted and Amazonian very quickly and it doesn't take much to get the balance of heat/humidity for 3 Star Product lines. Leaving the next logical path to delve into the Meth trade, but what If it was an option to continue evolving your Cannabis instead of migrating to meth. 

4 Progression Trees - 

1st Tree is Empire - Works as currently set up where you can progress to each trade and get 3 Instances of Each Product line for 9 options. 
2nd Tree is Grower - Unlocks a 4th and 5th Cannabis types but blocks off the 3rd Instance of Meth/Coke. 9 options
3rd Tree is Chemist - Unlock a 4th and 5th Meth type but blocks off 3rd Instances of Cannabis/Coke   9 options
4th Tree is Socialite - Unlocks a 4th and 5th Coke type but blocks off 3rd Instance of Cannabis/Meth   9 options

Progression can work similarly to Junk Yard/Uni/Guns where you send delivery out for skill points but you must purchase upgrades in order. First x amount of points unlocks the choice of a progression tree. The 4th and 5th products of each trade can be more complicated to get the right balance of temperatures/humidity/light (smaller thresholds) 

Staff - 

I enjoy managing the staff for each establishment but having to adjust the schedule can be tedious, Would love some options to click/drag to change states so we can make a full schedule easier without so much clicking. 



5/5 - This game is awesome for a Early Access game and I very much look forward to more like this!

140322355.review:
A interesting concept for a game but it feels like a alpha at best. 

1st the game is absurdly slow with progression you will spend entire days with the game just running at max speed to make enough money to do anything, because employee limits are tied to land which is expensive to start you'll grow your operation so slowly that you wish something, anything would happen but this leads to the next problem. Combind with how worthless your vehicles are til upgraded you've got alot of running the game in the background.

2, Nothing ever happens; There's only 2 scripted events in the game where you can even be attacked from what I can tell, both times tied to progress. Both of these attacks are not only completely unwinnable even if every single employee is a guard but there's a entire gameplay mechanic around hiring these guards and outfitting them, which you will never do since even if you could get attacked you don't have the employee limits to maintain any kind of force unless your leaving the game on overnight to afford half a coffee shop.

3, Logistic wise its nonexistant. You can't name routes, or vehicles, or set even the most basic of import limits for them to follow. So lets say you have a donut shop which is selling all 3 kinds of weed, you have space to store 12 of each. If you have 12 of #1, 10#2 and 0 of #3 and the vehicle pulls up with 1 of #1 and you got nowhere to put it, it will sit there forever til space is availible. This creates huge bottlenecks, which lead to workers sitting idle, customers complaining you don't have the right things availible for purchase, ect. 

4, AI workers work about 90% of 50% of the time. Your only control over workers is what hours they work, and what tasks and rooms they can be in. You can't prioritize any task over another e.g. Only haul to drivers if you have no Weed #2 related jobs availible, ect you can only say do both and it's random what they'll do. 

A good example of this is mechanics who will ignore broken machines (which the game won't tell you why, supposedly theres a 20 tile radius they work in and what that means exactly is never explained) as they wander around randomly even directly past broken equiptment and you can only set room groups for them to work in, so you'd think it would be all the devices in those rooms right? Wrong. 

5 Lastly, setting up your actual base is also a pita. There's no options to manually make walls dividing rooms or the like. So in the case of say Weed #2 and Weed #3 having conflicting requirements you'll need to seperate them by building completely superflous rooms with empty land inbetween instead of using a simple divider. Doing this spreads the base out further, which breaks the AI further. Most objects need the area infront of them completely unobstructed and can't share this space, which results in needing huge rooms to tetris objects in despite there being no reason why you can't make a trash can and soda machine can both face the same empty tile.

I could go on about a laundry list of other issues, customer complaints that you can't do anything about decoration (cuz it doesn't exist) or tempature (doesn't affect people), quest's that have absurdly short deadlines that are near impossible to do without express knowledge their about to happen like npc Jack asking for 20 of something in 10 in game minutes (hope you got 3 unused trucks and 4 pallets worth of it ready it's failed with a complete loss of all your stuff), ect ect. 

Maybe in couple years of dev this might be worth playing if they completely redo about 2/3 of the systems, but that's gonna be alot of work.

Get this game on sale or do not get it at all.

The gameplay loop will make for a fun weekend. The graphics and poor AI make for a fun experience which will get old 10 hours in.

You probably were interested in this game after seeing a trailer for it. It makes the game seem more complete then it is, even for early access. 

There are many things this game needs to address, including bugs that existed well before it was in early access. This is a game made by a single programmer. Bless his heart, I think he's genuinely trying to make this game into something. But its clear he is a bit out of his depth / that this is a passion project, not his 9-5 job.

The game would be much better if he just took a week and worked on it with nothing else. It'd also be better if he brought someone in to help with the interface / menus as the design makes Windows 98 look good.

For what this game was, I enjoyed it. If you're looking for something resembling Breaking Bad, this isn't it. This game is for the people who played Dope Wars on their calculators at school or who enjoyed Outwar - a browser based mafia game.

The closest thing to compare this game to is The Sims and that would be a diservice to The Sims.

Let this one cook a bit longer through EA and do not pay full price for it.

136896653.review:
This game hits so many right buttons for me that I have to recommend it. While there are plenty of problems and updates don't come out at a regular pace, I still believe this is worth a buy even at its current state. 

Where this game does right is the idea of building and maintaining both a lab and a front or fronts for your business of NOT selling chicken. Usually you'd only be in charge of procuring and then distributing product, well now you also get to make a KFC to sell less than legitimate products alongside some tasty chicken. This is great and it pleases my simple brain when I do, finally, manage to create a positive cash flow.

Where this game doesn't quite hit the mark is from a number of ongoing issues. There are a number of bugs that can effectively keep you from playing. Usually these are resolved by relauching the game, but having to do so multiple times per hour can become a real chore. This only becomes more tedious when loading times can be seen as on the long side(I currently have it on an SSD and it still takes a minute or two to get the game launched and back into my current save file.) 

Lastly, is a certain amount of imbalances in the game itself. At the start the tutorial gives you a rundown of how to start and maintain a business/front. These are relatively charming and simple to understand as you go. However, it has a way of kicking you into the lions den the moment it's over. You help repair and restart a business for another company and the moment you finish the business portion of the tutorial you get fired on the spot. The tutorial takes this chance to introduce you to your very own Sal lawyer guy as the explanation of the Not chicken side of things. The problem with this is the fact that it doesn't set you up for success as soon as they are done feeding you this side of things. You have a barely functioning 'Not chicken' lettuce supply and nothing else, it doesn't urge you to build a business outside of vaguely mentioning the teaching guides on the top before leaving you on your own. 

Tutorial aside this is the least of your worries at the start. You have only a production of 'lettuce' and no fronts, so now what? Well it gives you access to a group of bikes to deliver product, so that should be enough right? Sadly this is another point for imbalance. Your first orders over the request system is for eight pieces of 'Definitely Not Fried Chicken' each and each job has an output of somewhere between eight and nine hundred dollars. Great! However your starting bikes can only hold one piece of lettuce and makes for horribly slow progress. This becomes only worse when you sell your first piece of lettuce from a front(if you manage to get so far as to start the first of the 'optional' side tutorials) and find that each piece of lettuce sold is worth almost four hundred dollars! So this basically makes any deliveries to these requests completely unprofitable. 

TL;DR 

Where this game may have issues and I have a better ability to describe faults than praises due to my own inexperience with other management games like this to compare it to, it still manages to draw me in and peak my interest. I recommend it because it has so much potential and I want nothing more than to see where it goes as the developers put more love and care into it. 

After thought:

I was made to write this after discovering the strange disconnect between front lettuce money gain and the requests. This was such a huge problem that I had to put it somewhere! Please, developers, this is among your biggest issues that isn't the usual complaint about locked content. The balance between requests and fronts is astronomical and at the beginning the ability to actually survive as nothing but a dealer of 'not fried chicken' without a front is completely impossible without the access to trucks.

134227042.review:
This one of those games that has potential, it's just not quite there yet. I'll explain.

Right now it's two main issues are, lack of content (but there is plenty planned.) and issues with general game logic.
The lack of content is pretty much a guaranteed when considering Early Access titles, so I'll give this issue a free pass. However, there needs to be some major changes logic-wise in order for me to turn this frown upside down.

The building system is, how should I put it, rudimentary at best. There are certain exclusion zones around items that do not need to exist. For example, each tile can only hold one object, the tile adjacent to the object is it's 'interaction zone', you cannot place objects within an interaction zone, or overlap interaction zones. This is a big issue as, for example, doors have an interaction zone on either side. Thus making the building of rooms clunky. You can't, for example, put a door next to a microwave, a UV light (which hangs from the ceiling) over a planter and plenty more other small, yet highly frustrating issues.

The logistics system is similarly frustrating. If your business fills up on a particular stock, lets say regular cannabis, the car delivering 2 units of Cannabis, 1 unit of Toasted and 1 unit of Amazonian will sit there forever until you eventually sell 2 units of regular Cannabis and the vehicle is now empty. This clogs up the system and is highly inefficient, with larger logistics vehicles planned this will only get worse. 
What it should do is make a check to see if the assigned stores are full and if so, return to the depot or go to the next delivery assignment. Better yet, have the store check for what it needs and make the request from the factory to begin with.

Workers need a priority list of assignments. If there are customers waiting to be served and a logistics vehicle waiting to be emptied and you only have limited employees, the player should be able to decide which they want to tackle first. Rather than have to employ far more employees than necessary to cover all bases at all times. Just as with the logistics, this is highly inefficient.

Right now, I cannot recommend this game. Within a few hours I've pretty much seen all there is to see and spotted a few major issues that will grind the game down as more content is added. As far as the gameplay loop is concerned, it's great. It just needs a lot more mechanical refinement and about another year or two in the oven before it's ready. I don't regret spending the money as I see good potential in the future.

The good:
- Phenomenal gameplay loop
- Creative style
- Great direction as Early Access progresses
- Very well thought out attempt at granularity (which will be amazing over time as I'm sure it will be adjusted)
- Overall a fun time

The bad:
- People seem to get awkwardly stuck at random times. Had a line of workers stuck on a single hand dryer, laundromat workers spawning in an adjacent shop and getting stuck (never making it to work and hosing one of my businesses for a short while)
- Dispatch locations will sometimes overlap, making it almost impossible to click new locations underneath existing locations.

The ugly:
- This game memory leaks HORRIBLY. Over the course of an hour, I've watched my memory consumption go up 4GB. Once I save, exit, and load back in, it goes back down and slowly climbs up another 4GB over the next hour.
- Reloading a save (especially after clearing up the memory leak) completely clears dispatch routes. This makes it a nightmare loading back in when you have a lot of active orders

131815641.review:
TLDR; Really fun concept, game does have promise. Many issues need fixing. Not worth the price AT THE MOMENT.

Review: After spending a decent amount of time in this game, in it's current state I can't recommend buying it. Too much needs to be done.
Issues: 
* Character AI is terrible. Nothing worse than people you are paying to do a job standing around. (They are fixing this as a priority)
* Monuments do not work (known issue, added to the list)
* "upgraded" equipment does not offer any additional benefit (known issue)
* Delivery path finding needs work. Time sensitive deliveries and my drivers are doing circles around the block.
* two "employees" per purchase of production land is just not enough, needs re-balancing / increasing or have security personnel as it's own capacity and separated from workers.

Technical issues:
* Poorly optimised. Once your empire is "big" then game performance just tanks.
* After a relatively decent amount of playtime it chews through my RAM, using in excess of 10GB
* Random crashes, usually jumping from owned properties/fronts via the menu icon. (Save often)
* UI elements just stop working and are unresponsive randomly. Character equipment sheet and interacting with placeable objects mainly.

All this is known to the devs and I'm sure there are other issues I just have not raised.

Note to devs: Please change the default settings for any object that can be "filtered" for accepted items to nothing (default is set to accept EVERYTHING) upon placement rather it would be better to let me filter manually after placement. examples include: Storage shelves, delivery vehicles, processing equipment.  There is nothing more annoying than trying to add storage/delivery route for meth (or other products) and your workers charge in with hands full of everything else and start throwing it on a shelf. This is a QoL improvement that in my opinion is just needed.

Overall, when this game has had some more work and optimisation done to it, it will be a very chill, fun game. I will revisit this in the future and if they fix the issues I will change my recommendation but for now I cannot recommend it. Give it time.

Edit: grammatical and conciseness changes.

131553131.review:
For me this is a definite reccomend!

“you know that watermelon in Japan they grow by putting them in a box? Well, they did that but with people” - Dev

All my game time so far has been on the steam deck, so first of all, the games aesthetic is fitting and well done, it has that 80’s vibe as advertised. I’m not sure where the dev is from, but back in the 80’s we used to have these coffee/hot chocolate machines that look exactly like one of the drink machines in DNFC. I keep one in my drug factory kitchen, makes me smile every time I see it, reminds me of those sweet molten hot-hot chocolates at a hockey game/practice.

Another thing I really enjoy is the almost perfect balance of micromanagement and idler type of gameplay, there is just the right amount of mix, the drug making randos  require little input in to what they do, and more emphasis is placed on fine tuning your operations to find the right schedules, planning workflow, etc to get the most efficient operation as possible.

However one thing I find the game lacks, for me anyway, would be an optional “refinement method”. For instance with weed, I think something like adding curing as an optional process, having a curing station which would take additional time at a slower progress rate. Jar up the weed, let it sit for some time and add a “Top Shelf” quality level, or even a nutrient mix station which depending on your nutrient mix could make the plant grow mutant huge, crazy fast, double harvest amount. 

One major flaw I find at this point in the game would be I find the UI a tad clunky and unintuitive, but this is EA and I’m sure there are QOL and UI refinements in the future so this really isn’t a dealbreaker in my books. My other gripes are largely related to a few bugs, but again, not a dealbreaker for me.

One bug I found that made me giggle for hours was when one of my gardeners glitched up and he had a watering can stuck in his hand constantly spraying water, spraying water in bed, spraying water as he was being sprayed by water in the shower, eating meals, it was hilarious, everywhere this man went, he was spraying water, some say he still sprays water constantly to this day!

The game has only crashed on me once so far, and it was a really hard crash, frame rate plummeted and locked up my steam deck, so I had to get out of my lazy-boy to reset my Gaben deck, and this made me angry, until it didn’t.

I’m really hoping there will be more music added, while I like the music, I need a bit more variety.

Overall I really enjoy the game, yea the asking price as the game sits is a bit steep, but as a fan of tycoon games, I’ve spent more for less for sure. I like the fact the people in the game are grown in boxes on the ground in Japan like the watermelons, the game has some deep lore.

So easy buy for me, I hope the dev keeps going strong, as I’m excited to watch this game grow!

The tutorial is crap. To be honest, the things it explained well I could either figure out for myself or knew from other games. Several times I did what I thought was right but the tutorial wouldn't forward until I "randomly" tried other things. If you do something in the tutorial before it asks you to do it, you have to undo that thing and redo it for the tutorial to register that you did it. Several times when it did forward, I got a black screen with a movable cursor that made me have to start over again. And one time the tutorial just would not forward to the next part no matter what I did. And I clicked on every possible thing I could have. I just got a arrow point to something to click on and when I clicked on that button a new screen came up with another arrow. I click on that button and it takes me back to the first screen. Rinse and repeat. But none of these things seem to happen in the actual game. And I just skipped by the tutorial after awhile and was pretty much fine.

Some BIG annoying things in game is 1. you build these rooms with nice thick walls. But the toons don't respect the walls at all. They more often than not walk right through them. Original Review

Very Early Access, but a very good concept and it could be a great end product. I plan to update this review as the game develops. For now it is a recommend with caveats.

It's buggy right now and a large chunk of planned content isn't implemented yet, so don't buy if you're looking for a polished experience. That said, the bones of a good game are here, and I'm excited to see how this game evolves. I was excited to restart as I learned ways to make my operation more profitable or efficient, and the systems are engaging and complex enough that every run felt (and ended) different. 

Logistics plays a large role in everything on both a micro and macro scale. The distance between your workstations, the lengths of your hallways, and even the path your trucks must take to reach other destinations is something you'll want to keep in mind. I find that challenge stimulating, though I would like to see some further development. The ability to set task priorities for workers, box and ship intermediate production items (like uncooked donuts, for example), and the ability to set custom routes for transports would be great. To go from great to incredible would be implementing rotating availability of a larger number of purchasable properties and logistic hubs like warehouses or garages to allow for more complex supply chains.

This game has plenty of positives, but I currently would only recommend this to people who really enjoy management style games who are willing to support an unfinished game that shows potential. Some of the bugs currently being worked on should have been found with just regular play testing before release, there were some choices that felt like they were the result of a rushed release, and this game is too new to know for sure how the devs will progress, but I'm rooting for this game and I think it could be great.

[h1]EDIT: Updated Review at the Bottom[/h1]

So far, this game is a pretty good example of "EA" that people complain about the most.  I've been following this game for a year or 2 and was excited to see it finally out.  I normally don't have a problem with EA games and still can find some fun in them, but this game makes it hard to.

First off, it's the same ol' tale that you are seeing on reviews for this game: Tutorial sucks.  It really sucks.  It has you do the bare minimum and then just...stops.  I can't really say it just "stops."  More like that common movie trope where the dying old man is about you tell you the biggest secret in the whole universe but just gasps and dies.  Like Yoda, about to tell Luke about Vader, but just disappears into thin air.  Yeah, that's how this tutorial works out. 


Like others have said, Time is slow and I wish they fully explained it so I will.  Unlike games like the Sims, Two Point series, Planet Coaster/Zoo, when you hit the fast forward buttons, time moves very fast.  This game's option is normal, normalish, normallishish. See, you need to make deliveries to get paid, but the city is rather large and it takes quite a while to make a delivery.  Not to mention, each delivery requires 7 drop offs to get paid (which, btw, the tutorial never talks about). Clicking on the fastest option doesn't really help a thing.  I'm not asking to skip an entire day but can we have a sense of urgency?

Then there are several upgrades and items that have literal "EA" on them. I mean, that is expected in an Early Access title.


If for some reason you still want to get this game I have to tell you, be prepared to start a new game a few times until you can figure this mess out.  However, and this drives me crazy, if you need to start a new game, the only option you have is to exit out of the whole game, open the game up again in Steam and then choose a new game. There is no way to "Exit to Main Menu."  I don't understand how basic menu features are none existent in this game that allows you to have multiple saves.  

I love management games and this one is unique and right up my alley.  However, they decided to be a little too unique with their strange design choices, that I can't recommend this game AS IS.  I can see this game being better in 6 months and even "Great" by the time it leaves Early Access.  Devs have already been acknowledging a lot of the bugs and hopefully some QOL.  As for now, wait a bit.

[h1]UPDATED REVIEW:[/h1] 

So, I've added several hours to this game but don't let that you fool you.  In order to get a good chunk of money going, I highly recommend letting the game run as you go do chores/work/errands and etc.  With more money in the bank you'll be able to explore more about the game.  In doing so, I have found out more things I dislike about this game:

Things that have AOE (Area of Effect) are pretty trash in this game right now.  There are certain conditions that need to be met in order to grow a high quality drug such as temperature and light.  You have basic UV lights, heaters, AC and etc.  You can also get upgrade these things like Over Head Grow lights or Large Heaters but they pretty much suck/useless.  You'd think you'd be able to put overhead lights, well, overhead your plants.  You can't.  You figure that putting a Large Heater, right in front of your product would be sufficient enough.  Wrong.  You put it at a specific angle that doesn't make any sense.  

Employees at your restaurants are constantly dropping things.  I've seen 3 year olds with iron like grips compared to these but wholes. I've once watched an employee pick up and drop the same burger 4 times in a row, leave it, then eventually come back before dropping it 2 more times. The worst part is, when they drop the food it becomes contaminated and will make customers sick who will eventually die (luckily there is no penalty for this...yet).  There is no way to get rid of the contaminated food.  You can't even put a garbage can in the kitchen for these but wholes to just throw it away.  

Employees also seem to have a mind of their own and will outright refuse to do tasks that YOU have told them to do.  For some reason, my employees really hate making glazed donuts, even though they are tasked to do it, and the glazed donuts have their very own station and dedicated fryer and they refuse to make it.  You can fire employees but  I really hope they eventually add in the ability to just kill off these useless employees.

Who also thought it was a great idea to make the burger fryer a special but-whole unit that must have a heater next to it or else it will explode?  If you do not maintain this thing with a heater (awkwardly placed, taking up valuable space) and maintenance man, it will explode and set your whole kitchen on fire.  

Game crashes at the weirdest times too.  "Oh, whats that?  You wanted to check on your employee's condition?" Crash. "Oh, you like saving because I'm in EA?" Crash. "Oh, that youtube video you were watching went into a commercial break?" Crash! (This literally happened last night to me).

This is really tough for me.  I really do see the potential of this game and it's going to be fun, when it's fixed up, but it's current state is making me start to hate it.  I'm still sticking with my original review that this game is a big NO.  I'll keep testing this product, for you and the devs, and will update when its working.

131367495.review:
The game has some work needed, but overall I think it's pretty good.  

For the devs: the biggest problem I have with it at this point is that it needs a better system for distributing your wares.  The mopeds and cars are a great idea, but the problem is that it's pretty tedious and difficult to see at a glance what is happening logistically.  

As an example, you get calls in the neighborhood requesting your goods.  You have to assign vehicles you own to take the goods to the location.  This is fine at first, but it quickly becomes obvious that there will be a lot of these requests and you'll have to be going into the dispatch screen to just tell your cars to go to a bunch of places.  I think this detracts from the game a good bit.

Also, there's not really a good way to distribute goods efficiently to the other businesses you own.  Cars get sent to locations regardless of how full the local storage is, meaning they could just be sitting overnight (since inventory is static at night) and only keep doing the rounds late in the morning.  Distribution could be automatic--stores request goods they want--or you could make a new job "the dispatcher" to handle those logistics.  Either way, the logistics are not great.

I think the limit on factory workers based on plots owned doesn't make a lot of sense and it's a little unbalanced.  At the current setting, I don't see a way to defend my factory and still produce.  Maybe this was intentional since attacks don't yet seem to be a thing.

Still some buggy things but overall, very nice little game.

This game is a mixed bag, there are some great design decisions - and there are some terrible ones. Since it only literally just came out to EA I'll give it a pass, but there are for sure issues that need ironing out, or even systems that need massive improvement or redoing entirely.

- Game can be addictive
- Upgradable equipment on your workers
- Research is done tastefully
- Research options are neat and game changing

Stuff I didn't like as much:

- Having a "interactivity" area in front of certain objects is incredibly frustrating when building rooms; it feels needless to have them at times for certain objects. (Looking at you, ceiling lights.)

- Events

- More decoration options
- More naunce when it comes to making drugs; right now its just AOE emitters and how much you can afford

131140407.review:
[b]Tentatively recommended -[/b]
It is early access meaning at least half of the content is locked out, the concept is great, it generally plays well and it's not that hard to figure things out as you go. It's buggy (I found an infinite money glitch already) but overall not bad. At this stage it's fun and I see potential.

[b]What's currently working -[/b]
3/3 strains of weed production
1/3 strains of meth production
0/3 strains of cocaine production
3/6 front businesses

[b]What's fun -[/b]
Optimising the different aspects of the businesses, finding strategies that work and setting long term plans that are paying off.
I like the idea of buttering up local businesses with drugs to get upgrades and technology.

[b]What appears to be missing -[/b]
Actual risk to running your operation, there is an initial raid then seemingly nothing afterwards.
Any degree of police presence in the world outside of vehicles.

[b]What isn't going so well -[/b]
Deliveries feel like they need to be micromanaged, it seems that whatever you deliver to a location will be taken regardless if it's on the order or not, meaning you cannot comfortably set your vehicles and forget.
Deliveries feel like they are huge, initial deliveries are 8 boxes of product, your first vehicle only holds a single box. Not only does this cause an incredibly slow early game, it can mean you can't actually stay afloat despite having stock. (It's also unrealistic to drop off massive amounts of product to suburban houses)
Once a vehicle is loaded, it no longer shows what is inside.
Employees will straight up fucking work themselves to death if they don't have a sufficient break in their schedule (the default schedule does not).

[b]Suggestions -[/b]
Number the player's delivery vehicles on the map, their garage and on the vehicle itself.
Show what each vehicle is holding both on the delivery map and in the garage.
Prevent vehicles from unloading hotline deliveries if that product isn't outstanding.
Allow vehicles to queue to dropoff rather than just driving around the block.
Set a supply limit for front businesses so that delivery vehicles can actually supply more than one at a time.
If an employee hits critical on one of their needs, let them go and deal with it like a normal person would, this game isn't set in Soviet Russia.

In the end, I personally like it, but I'd recommend giving it some more time in the oven to flesh out the major features. Right now it's a very solid foundation, it's good but it's not crispy yet.

131124560.review:
[b] Target Audience: [/b]  Very Patient Players......Very Patient. [I] [/i]

[b] Summary: [/b]  

I admit, this one drove me up the wall. Look, I get that games may be a little rough in early access, and I try to keep an open mind when it comes to the gameplay to give updates. I know that a simulation genre is also one that it's a little bit tricky to do in early access: with multiple mechanics to refine and to mess with. But the first impression that Definitely Not Fried Chicken made with me was bad: and seem to frustrate me at every turn. Whether it being missing elements to snap back to our main area, confusing icons, or just not giving enough of a tutorial on certain things, all I could think was about other games like it that wouldn't be frustrating me as much as this one was.

I mean look, if your employees literally are at 0 food or hygiene, and you can't specifically tell them to do that task, I expect the AI to be like “oh, I'm going to die. I probably should deal with this.” Instead, they went and watched TV. Like that's the kind of things that frustrated me through the game, whether it be apparently being able to build over my area with a road that I definitely didn't want, or having items take up way too much space on the playable area (why do I need two spaces for a wall dryer?!?). Frustrating controls aside: you don't even really get into the front part of the game until a bit later, and a rea at that point, you're just wanting to stab yourself to remove yourself from the experience.

Like, maybe it'll build into a game worth something down the road. But right now, I have no confidence in the base product because there's so many problems left and right. 


[b]Stream Footage:    [/b]  https://youtu.be/aIaRlLtjpgY


[u] Lists: [/u]
[b]Positives:[/b]
[list]
[*] A bit of mechanics. 
[*] Some ok visuals. 
 [/list]

[b]Negatives:[/b]
[list]
[*] The pace of the mechanics is so fast and so many, that you can't keep track of everything when the game lets go and you get confused.
[*] The game's tutorial teaches you some mechanics....but not others. And then sorta makes you try to figure out things on the way.
[*] UI at times is frustrating to get through and keybinds for things you'd figure that you'd want (go to the base of your operation for example) aren't here.
[*] The game feels overly complex in certain areas (the schedule for example) that maybe should have waited to be introduced down the road.
[*] The worker AI will literally let itself be killed even if you literally try to tell it “hey, take the time you need, get yourself well.” It will ignore things like a shower and will watch TV instead if that one is semi-low, oh by the way YOU DIED DURING THAT TIME.
[*] Glitches like values staying on your mouse or people going through walls are common. 
[*] The game takes a LONG time to load the first time around....on a machine that can games with 25x complexity in an instant. 
[*] Just frustrating.
 [/list]

131095626.review:
READ WHOLE THING PLEASE

Okay so yes I'm giving it a thumbs up. But the game isn't perfect and it's definitely got problems. I'm only giving it a thumbs up because there's no middle ground neutral button and I don't think it deserves a thumbs down.

Technically the game does what it sets out to do. It's a simulator game about drug peddling. The management is decent, the gameplay is sufficient and the loop is kinda fun and addictive. So because it does those fairly well it gets a thumbs up.

HOWEVER

The game is broken to the point it almost crashed my PC half a dozen times. No i'm not exaggerating. During it's loading screen it freezes at minimal twice per loading screen and almost crashes every time.

Then you've got certain functions simply not working. Game asked me to place a break room. I tried but nothing happened but the game still thought that it was built so it wanted me to continue doing the tutorial, only I couldn't. 

So the game is still very unstable and honestly every time I try to open up the game I get nervous that it's going to destroy my PC.

Plus the game is very unfinished, missing a lot of content which I suppose makes sense because it's early access but still I thought I should say so.

And then you've got some functions of the gameplay that are downright poorly designed and need to be adjusted. Like the delivering of your goods to yoru customers. They take one box at a time, it's super slow and half the time you'll find yourself just staring at your screen for 5-10 minutes just waiting for orders to be completed while you're depleting money the whole time. The delivery needs to be sped up somehow or something I don't know but it needs to be more engaging then that.

Also I don't think that the pricetag is appropriate for this kind of game. Pixelated graphics. No voice acting. Generic sound effects. Repetetive gameplay loop.

Don't get me wrong, it's not a bad game, but I still think that the price tag is a bit too much for an investment. They are making us pay them to playtest their game and I think it's too much.

If you'd like a more in depth look at the game with more information then please check out the video I posted on my YouTube Channel. (Link Below).

Otherwise thanks a bunch for reading and I hope I managed to help some of you out there to spend your money wisely.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O9A12vZnwhI
131095626.developer_response: Hey! 100% agree with the points made, we'll be addressing bugs, QOL, crashes and tooltips as we roll content and updates out, thanks for your indepth review!

131090480.review: Purchased the pre-early access version of this game a few months ago. It is addicting. It has (or had) it's issues, but it has huge potential. Despite a few minor bugs I've come across, I am really excited that this game is now on early access. It is way too much fun managing your drug manufacturing on top of managing your day-to-day store fronts to push your product. As long as the developers keep up with what they have been doing during development, I think this game can be huge. I spent $20 on the pre-EA build and don't know how much it's selling for on early access, but the $20 I spent feels completely worth it in my opinion. This isn't the most in depth review ever, but I just wanted to give my love for this game and it's devs and also congrats to the developers for reaching early access!
